awd_titl_txt: Stereoselective Assembly of Oxindole Alkaloid Natural Products
awd_abstract_narration:
With this Award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Brandon L. Ashfeld at the University of Notre Dame. The awarded proposal is focused on the development of new methods that address critical challenges in the synthesis of complex, high value molecular targets. The primary objective is to develop a suite of new tools that enable access to the core molecule scaffolds present in biologically relevant alkaloid natural products. The overarching strategy focuses on exploiting the reactivity of a single carbon component attainable from readily available precursors for accessing a diverse array of related targets. A key aspect of this proposal is the integration of research findings in the laboratory introduction of undergraduates and the training of graduate students in synthetic methods design and development. Undergraduate and graduate students are more likely to pursue advanced degrees in chemistry and careers in research and discovery when presented with a target-specific pedagogical approach toward chemical education. The incorporation of target-based instruction as it pertains to the molecular assembly of specific chemical functionality, rather than the traditional reaction-centered lab design prevalent today, is central to the broader impacts of this project.

Despite the ubiquitous presence of 5-membered carbocycles and heterocycles in natural products chemistry and chemical biology, the number of reliable methods for the assembly of highly substituted rings with flexible site-specific functionalization capabilities is relatively limited. This project focuses on the development of new synthetic strategies toward alkaloid frameworks that address several key long-standing challenges in small molecule construction through the design and implementation of (4+1)- and (4+3)-cycloadditions. Specific objectives include the 1) the enantioselective synthesis of the spiropyrrolidine oxindole scaffold employing a formal (4+1)- cycloaddition; 2) enantioselective formal (4+3)-cycloaddition synthesis of the cycloheptane oxindole core of the welwitindolinone alkaloids; and 3) the stereoselective construction of spirocyclopentenone oxindoles by expanding the architectural diversity of available vinyl ketenes. Implementation of this design enables access to various polycyclic scaffolds bearing a central 5- or 7-membered ring. Toward that end, this project addresses challenges associated with the 1) convergent assembly of both 5- and 7-membered rings with the flexibility to provide carbo- and N-heterocyclic frameworks, 2) construction of a key stereogenic carbon with proximal functionality for subsequent manipulations, and 3) control of relative and absolute stereochemistry. The prevalence of these ring frameworks in translationally relevant targets highlights the scientific broader impacts of this work in chemical biology and therapeutics development. Additionally, the long-range significance of this study is its impact on C–C and C–N bond assembly in fields such as process flow chemistry and bioorthogonal reaction development. The synthetic methods developed form the basis for a cohesive pedagogical approach to laboratory instruction that will broadly impact STEM education efforts at all levels. By emphasizing target analysis, rather than reaction introduction, a cohesiveness between comprehension at the conceptual level and application to the synthesis of complex molecules is to be achieved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The research outcomes that were generated from the National Science Foundation funded project CHE 1956170 related directly to the development of new methods and synthetic strategies in organic chemistry to more efficiently and cost effectively construct complex molecular scaffolds that are relevant to current and future needs in the pharmaceutical industry and materials science. The stereoselective construction of quaternary stereogenic carbons and the assembly of functionalized, highly substituted heterocyclic frameworks constitutes two main challenges in synthetic organic chemistry. This project sought to address both of these hurdles commonly encountered in complex molecule construction through the development of complementary enantioselective, transition metal-catalyzed [4+n]-cycloadditions involving a metallocarbene as formal C1-synthon. During the funding period, we sought to accomplish these tasks by 1) conducting a comprehensive mechanistic investigation of our previously disclosed [4+1]-cycloadditions between diazo compounds and either a vinyl ketene or vinyl isocyanate that would form the basis for a an enantioselective entry into the pyrrolidinone framework, 2) extending our efforts to the cycloheptaindolone scaffold prevalent in the welwitindolinone family of biologically active alkaloid natural products, and 3) expanding the architectural diversity and general utility of highly reactive vinyl ketenes in complex molecule construction through the development of alternative strategies that avoids the structural limitations of previously disclosed methods. Specifically, significant accomplishments over the course of the funding period include:

  1. Through an extensive investigation of the mechanisms for complementary cyclopropyl ketene and cyclopropyl isocyanate rearrangements in collaboration with Professor Olaf Wiest (University of Notre Dame) we unveiled compelling evidence in support two distinctly different mechanistic pathways that explain the disparate stereochemical outcomes of enantioenriched cyclopropanes. Results in support of a concerted 1,3-migration that exhibits short-lived radical character in the case of vinyl ketenes, while cyclopropyl vinyl isocyanates undergo ring expansion through a polar mechanism by virtue of the donor-acceptor cyclopropane relationship rationalizes the loss of optical enrichment in the latter case that is not observed with vinyl ketenes.
  2. Using these mechanistic findings as a foundation toward the development of an enantioselective entry into the spiropyrrolidinone scaffold, we established the efficacy of a Rh(I)-catalyzed [4+1]-cycloaddition between a diazo compound and vinyl isocyanate that avoids the cyclopropyl isocyanate intermediate. Proof of concept and optimization experiments were concluded that resulted in our ability to obtain the desired cycloadducts in excellent yields. These results preclude our efforts toward an enantioselective protocol that has eluded us by virtue of rendering a reductive elimination as the enantiodetermining step rather than a cyclopropane ring expansion.
  3. Along our investigations involving the inclusion alternative [m+1]-cycloadditions, we established two new methods toward cyclobutenes and 2,6-disubstituted pyrans through the interception of a Pd-carbenoid derived from a Pd(II) complex and the corresponding diazo compound. The inclusion of chiral phosphines enabled the construction of these high value motifs in an enantioselective fashion.
  4. of TMM intermediates in metallocarbene cycloadditions, we discovered that the introduction of an aldehyde led to the formation of 2,2,6-trisubstituted pyrans in a completely diastereoselective fashion. This scaffold is ubiquitous in many macrolides that are biologically relevant with anticancer and antibiotic activity. Current and future efforts are focused on expanding on this initial discovery to develop a method that will allow convergent assembly of this critical heterocyclic framework in the context of complex natural product synthesis.
  5. Significant efforts toward establishing a stereoselective entry into the welwitindolinone tricyclic core through a Rh(II)-catalyzed [4+3]-cycloaddition of chiral and achiral vinyl allenes and diazooxindoles led to the establishment of three new avenues of research. These include the ability to control cycloheptaindolone, oxepine, and spirocyclopentenone oxindoles through a combination of catalyst selection and substrate architecture. 
  6. Provided the foundation for further development of a [4+1]-cycloaddition employing an in situ generated Cu-allenylidene as a replacement for the vinyl ketene and vinyl isocyanate components.
  7. Successfully applied our [4+1]-cycloaddition technology to the convergent and streamlined construction of various heterocyclic frameworks of translational significance as selective kinase inhibitors. 

The findings that resulted from this funded project were disseminated in over 10 publications published in reputable, peer reviewed journals recognized internationally as leaders in their respective areas, provided the framework for subsequent studies based on synthetic methods development and target-directed synthesis. The personnel outcomes associated with this award include four doctoral theses, and enabled 11 undergraduates at the University of Notre Dame to gain valuable research experience that will serve them throughout their future research and medical careers. The broad educational outcomes and outreach objectives that were achieved throughout the execution of this project included community outreach to area high schools designed to encourage collegiate pursuits and progress toward the development of a synthetic target-based approach toward undergraduate laboratory instruction.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Brandon Ashfeld

The stereoselective construction of quaternary stereogenic carbons and the assembly of functionalized, highly substituted heterocyclic frameworks constitutes two main challenges in synthetic organic chemistry. Using these mechanistic findings as a foundation toward the development of an enantioselective entry into the spiropyrrolidinone scaffold, we established the efficacy of a Rh(I)-catalyzed [4+1]-cycloaddition between a diazo compound and vinyl isocyanate that avoids the cyclopropyl isocyanate intermediate. Along our investigations involving the inclusion alternative [m+1]-cycloadditions, we established two new methods toward cyclobutenes and 2,6-disubstituted pyrans through the interception of a Pd-carbenoid derived from a Pd(II) complex and the corresponding diazo compound. of TMM intermediates in metallocarbene cycloadditions, we discovered that the introduction of an aldehyde led to the formation of 2,2,6-trisubstituted pyrans in a completely diastereoselective fashion. Current and future efforts are focused on expanding on this initial discovery to develop a method that will allow convergent assembly of this critical heterocyclic framework in the context of complex natural product synthesis.
Significant efforts toward establishing a stereoselective entry into the welwitindolinone tricyclic core through a Rh(II)-catalyzed [4+3]-cycloaddition of chiral and achiral vinyl allenes and diazooxindoles led to the establishment of three new avenues of research. These include the ability to control cycloheptaindolone, oxepine, and spirocyclopentenone oxindoles through a combination of catalyst selection and substrate architecture.
Provided the foundation for further development of a [4+1]-cycloaddition employing an in situ generated Cu-allenylidene as a replacement for the vinyl ketene and vinyl isocyanate components.
Successfully applied our [4+1]-cycloaddition technology to the convergent and streamlined construction of various heterocyclic frameworks of translational significance as selective kinase inhibitors.



 The findings that resulted from this funded project were disseminated in over 10 publications published in reputable, peer reviewed journals recognized internationally as leaders in their respective areas, provided the framework for subsequent studies based on synthetic methods development and target-directed synthesis. The personnel outcomes associated with this award include four doctoral theses, and enabled 11 undergraduates at the University of Notre Dame to gain valuable research experience that will serve them throughout their future research and medical careers. The broad educational outcomes and outreach objectives that were achieved throughout the execution of this project included community outreach to area high schools designed to encourage collegiate pursuits and progress toward the development of a synthetic target-based approach toward undergraduate laboratory instruction.
